paper_id: Temporal andspatial variation of potassium balance in agricultural land at national and regional levels in China

paper_metadata.title: Temporal and spatial variation of potassium balance in agricultural land at national and regional levels in China
paper_metadata.research_focus: Evaluation of temporal and spatial variation in potassium (K) balances and K use efficiency in agricultural land across China from 1980 to 2015.
paper_metadata.soil_k_relevance: The study is entirely focused on soil K, specifically its balance (inputs vs. outputs), use efficiency, and its temporal and spatial dynamics at national and regional levels in China's agricultural systems.

research_context.study_objectives: To evaluate the temporal and spatial variation in K balances and K use efficiency in China from 1980 to 2015. The results aim to help identify regions with poor soil fertility and assist in putting forward strategies for rational nutrient management to improve low-yielding fields.
research_context.soil_k_research_role: Soil K balance is the central theme of the research, analyzed through its inputs, outputs, and overall net change, as well as K use efficiency.
research_context.geographic_setting: Mainland China, excluding Hong Kong and Macao, divided into six regions (Northeast, North China, Northwest, Middle-Lower Yangtze River, Southeast, Southwest) based on geographical locations and administrative divisions.
research_context.environmental_conditions: The study focuses on agricultural land. Climate conditions are briefly mentioned in relation to K fixation (alternation of dry and wet climate conditions in NW).
research_context.agricultural_context: Agricultural land-use systems, including crop production (cereals, fruit & vegetables, oil crops, industrial crops, root crops), chemical fertilizer application, organic manure (human and livestock manure), and straw return.
research_context.study_design: Observational study using statistical data and related parameters. Gross soil K balance was calculated based on 31 provincial data sets. Data pre-processing included original data verification, filling missing data, data validation, and derivative data construction. K balance was compared across four decades: 1980s (1980–1989), 1990s (1990–1999), 2000s (2000–2009), and 2010s (2010–2015).
research_context.temporal_scope: 36 years, from 1980 to 2015, with analysis grouped into four decades.
research_context.spatial_scope: National level and six distinct agricultural regions of China, based on provincial data.

temporal_patterns.monitoring_frequency: Annual data, analyzed and presented by four decades (1980s, 1990s, 2000s, 2010s).

long_term_trends.trend_description: Showed a consistent increasing trend over time.
Deficient from 1980 to 1997, gradually alleviated from 1984 to 1995, then reached a slight surplus and remained relatively stable from 2003 to 2015.
long_term_trends.statistical_significance: Not explicitly stated for overall trend, but values show clear shift.
Reflected by decline of slope in K input vs. K output graph.

long_term_trends.trend_description: All six regions showed an increasing trend over time, despite two fluctuations in 1995 and 2005.
long_term_trends.statistical_significance: Increased significantly over the past four decades for all regions, except NE and NC (maintained same level in 2000s and 2010s) and NW (no increase between 1980s and 1990s).

long_term_trends.trend_description: Generally increased over time in all regions, with some fluctuations.
long_term_trends.statistical_significance: Increased significantly over the past four decades for all regions, except NE (increased from 1980s to 1990s, then stabilized).

long_term_trends.trend_description: Varied widely. SE moved into surplus from 1985. NE remained negative. NC, SW, MLYR reached balance by 2002. NW was slightly in surplus and stable. Negative stage of K balance could be divided into a decrease and then an increase.
long_term_trends.statistical_significance: K balances in NE, MLYR, SE, and SW all increased significantly with time. NW decreased over time. NC increased from 1980s to 2000s, then decreased.

event_responses.soil_k_response: Short-term decrease in K balance in SE.
event_responses.recovery_pattern: K balance in SE increased again after 1998, remaining relatively stable after 2005.

between_site_differences.site_comparison: SE had the highest K input, followed by NC, MLYR, and SW. NE and NW had the lowest. Significant differences observed between regions.
MLYR, SE, and SW had high K output. NC, NE, and NW had lower K output. Significant differences observed between regions.
SE had the largest K balance surplus. NE and MLYR had significantly lower K balances, with NE remaining in deficit. NW was stable at equilibrium. NC and SW were negative initially, then in surplus.
Great spatial variability in KUE existed across different regions. SE had the lowest KUE (73.97% average, 56.53% in 2010s) due to overuse of K fertilizer. NE had the highest average KUE (138.63%).

scaling_considerations.scale_transition: From provincial data to national and regional levels.
scaling_considerations.scaling_approach: Aggregating 31 provincial data sets into national and six regional categories.
scaling_considerations.uncertainty: Not explicitly quantified, but the study emphasizes the importance of national-level analysis over specific experimental sites or short-term studies.

cycling_processes.description: Calculated as the difference between K inputs and K outputs in the agricultural system.

quantification.inputs: Chemical fertilizer, organic manure (human and animal manure, straw, cake manure), atmospheric dry and wet deposition, irrigation, crop seeds.
quantification.outputs: Crops removal (grain and straw uptake), nutrient loss (leaching and runoff loss).

cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Model-based calculation using statistical data and literature-derived parameters.

cycling_processes.description: Release of K from soil reserves, contributing to K availability for crop absorption.
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Inferred as a substantial role in regions with K deficit but stable available K (e.g., NE).

plant_soil_interactions.description: Crops remove K from the soil, which is a principal nutrient output.

quantitative_data.K_requirement_per_unit_yield: Table 3 provides kg K2O t-1 for various crops (e.g., Winter wheat: 27.14 kg K2O t-1, Vegetables: 4.85 kg K2O t-1, Sunflower: 93.22 kg K2O t-1).
quantitative_data.K_content_in_straw: Table 2 provides K2O in air-dry straw (%) for various crops (e.g., Rice: 2.053%, Wheat: 1.472%, Maize: 1.276%).

plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: Proportion of K removal by cereals decreased (70.2% to 55.8%), while fruit & vegetables (high K uptake) increased (8.7% to 24.1%) over four decades.
influencing_factors: K requirement for unit of economic yield

plant_soil_interactions.description: Crop residues returned to soils, contributing to K input.

quantitative_data.straw_return_rates: 1980s: ~1/3 of 2000s (5% in NE/NW, 20% in NC, 10% in MLYR/SE/SW); 1990s: ~2/3 of 2000s (10% in NE/NW, 40% in NC, 20% in MLYR/SE/SW); 2000s & 2010s: 15% in NE/NW, 60% in NC, 30% in MLYR/SE/SW.

plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: Ratio of straw return increased over time (9.0% in 1980s to 12.4% in 2000s/2010s of total K input).

chemical_processes.characterization: K becoming less available due to binding with soil components.
environmental_controls: Alternation of dry and wet climate conditions (e.g., in NW)
chemical_processes.implications: Can lead to decreasing K availability despite K balance being stable or in surplus.

soil_k_impacts.K_input_increase: Increased dramatically over time, becoming a larger contributor to total K input (from 10.2% in 1980s to 44.5% in 2010s).
soil_k_impacts.K_balance_improvement: Contributed to the shift from K deficit to surplus nationally.
soil_k_impacts.KUE_decrease: Increased K application rate led to diminished effect on grain production and decreased KUE.

management_practices.implementation_details: Varies by region and year (S1 Table for K2O ratio in compound fertilizer).
management_practices.spatial_effects: SE showed dramatic increase in chemical fertilizer application, leading to substantial K surplus. NW had low chemical K fertilizer application.

management_practices.practice: Organic manure application (human and livestock manure)

soil_k_impacts.K_input_contribution: Accounted for a substantial proportion of total K input (e.g., 65.9% in 1980s), but showed a decreasing trend in proportion over time.
soil_k_impacts.K_balance_contribution: Cow urine contributed substantially to K balance (e.g., in SE, reduction in cattle numbers led to K balance decrease).

management_practices.implementation_details: Parameters include livestock feeding period, daily excretion, K2O content, and application rates to field (Table 1). Application rates to field decreased over time (e.g., 55% in 1980s to 30-65% in 2000s/2010s depending on livestock type).
management_practices.temporal_effects: K input from human and livestock manure increased substantially from 1980 to 2015 (average annual increment of 0.11 Mt K2O).

soil_k_impacts.K_input_contribution: Increased over time (from 9.0% in 1980s to 12.4% in 2000s/2010s of total K input).
soil_k_impacts.K_balance_improvement: An important reason for improved K balance, especially with agricultural mechanization development.
soil_k_impacts.K_balance_sufficiency: Alone, not sufficient to maintain soil K balance over long-term.

management_practices.implementation_details: Rates varied by decade and region (e.g., 1980s: 1/3 of 2000s rates; 1990s: 2/3 of 2000s rates; 2000s/2010s: 15% in NE/NW, 60% in NC, 30% in MLYR/SE/SW).
management_practices.temporal_effects: K input from straw return increased substantially from 1980 to 2015 (average annual increment of 0.07 Mt K2O).

treatments_compared: Adjusted practices (zero growth chemical fertilizer, 60% straw/manure return)

soil_k_differences.SE_potential_decrease: K surplus over 70% in recent years, potential for decreasing K fertilizer application by 202.29 kg K2O ha-1 to maintain equilibrium.
soil_k_differences.NE_NW_need_increase: Still deficient in NE, and NW soil available K decreased, essential to apply more K fertilizer timely and efficiently.

comparative_analysis.statistical_significance: Not statistically tested, but based on balance calculations and KUE.

analytical_methods.procedure_description: Calculated as the difference between K inputs (chemical fertilizer, organic manure, atmospheric dry and wet deposition, irrigation, crop seeds) and K outputs (crops removal, nutrient loss (leaching and runoff loss)). Parameters for K balance calculations were explained in Liu et al. [39].
quality_control: Filling missing data (referring to statistical yearbook/published literature or adjacent years)
Data validation (data from adjacent years could not vary by more than 15%)
Derivative data construction (e.g., straw amount from grain yield and conversion factor)

analytical_methods.procedure_description: Calculated as the crops removal (K output in crops) divided by the total K input of a system.

sampling_design.spatial_sampling: Based on 31 provincial data sets in mainland China. China divided into six regions for analysis. Spatial variation of parameters estimated by region.
sampling_design.temporal_sampling: Data from 1980 to 2015 (annual data), analyzed in four decadal periods (1980s, 1990s, 2000s, 2010s).
sampling_design.sample_processing: Data pre-processing included filling missing data, data validation, and derivative data construction.
sampling_design.storage_handling: A reasonable database was built, including provincial K balance data.
sampling_design.representativeness: Aims to represent national and regional agricultural land in China.

uncertainty_sources: Difficulty in quantifying accurate amounts of K2O leaching and runoff outputs (though noted as small percentage of total output).
Reliance on statistical yearbooks and published literature for parameters and missing data.

climate_conditions.seasonality: Not specified, but 'alternation of dry and wet climate conditions' mentioned for NW region.

soil_properties.classification: Not explicitly classified, but 'cinnamon soil' mentioned in a reference.
soil_properties.mineralogy: Mentioned 'high soil K supply capacity with high K-containing minerals such as micas and feldspars in the soil parent material' in some regions.
soil_properties.organic_matter: Not specified, but organic manure and straw return are key inputs.

chemical_properties.soil_k_supply_capacity: High in some regions, influencing K fertilizer response.
chemical_properties.soil_available_k: Monitored and discussed in relation to K balance (e.g., stable in NE, decreased in NW).

landscape_context.position: Not specified, but 'agricultural land' is the general context.
landscape_context.land_use_history: Historical context of K deficiency in China (1961-1997) and subsequent relief with increased fertilizer K and straw return.

research_integration.relationship_to_other_measurements: K balance is directly linked to K use efficiency (KUE). The study also relates K balance to crop yield and soil fertility.
research_integration.integration_with_plant_studies: K requirement for unit of economic yield of different crops and K content in straw are key parameters in the K balance model, directly linking soil K to plant uptake and removal.
research_integration.connection_to_broader_objectives: The study aims to contribute to efficient use of K resources, food security, resource sustainability, optimizing nutrient use in agricultural systems, maintaining sustainability of soil nutrient resources, and informing national fertilizer policies.
research_integration.comparative_context: Compares findings with previous studies on K balance and deficiency in China (e.g., Liu et al. [25], Shen et al. [13], Sheldrick et al. [24]) and globally (Europe, Africa, Asia, North America).
research_integration.literature_positioning: Addresses the gap of long-term, national-level K balance studies, building upon previous site-specific or short-term observations.

measurement_constraints: Few published reports quantifying accurate amounts of K2O leaching and runoff outputs, requiring reliance on available values (though this output type accounted for a small percentage).
spatial_limitations: The study is based on statistical data, not direct soil measurements, which might limit in-depth analysis of element balances based on specific experimental sites.
methodological_constraints: The K balance model relies on conversion factors and parameters from literature surveys, which may introduce uncertainties.
interpretation_caveats: Long-term negative K balance is a potential problem even if not apparent in the short term.
K fertilizer application does not produce results as quickly as N and P fertilizer due to high soil K supply capacity in some soils.
Straw return alone may not be sufficient to maintain soil K balance.
K fixation due to dry/wet climate conditions or slow mineralization of returned straw can decrease K availability.
Nutrient management recommendations must change with yield levels and profit maximization.

extraction_assessment.extraction_notes: The paper is highly focused on K balance, providing extensive quantitative data and context. The 'pool characterizations' section was adapted to reflect the K balance components (inputs/outputs) as these are the 'pools' quantified in the study, rather than traditional soil K pools like exchangeable K, which were not directly measured or reported in this macro-level study. All relevant numerical data and their contexts were extracted.

_usage_metadata.paper_id: Temporal andspatial variation of potassium balance in agricultural land at national and regional levels in China
